cmCourseInfo.description: An investigation of the relationship between human beings and their natural and built environments. This interdisciplinary course will draw from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities to explore major social, cultural, economic, regulatory, ethical, ecological and technological aspects of environmental issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Environmental Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are Online, Synchronous; Tutorials are Online, synchronous

The lectures will be delivered synchronously online during scheduled class times (Thursdays from 3 to 5 pm), and with portions dedicated for discussion via Quercus. Lectures will be supplemented with pre-recorded interviews I have had with our authors and my own discussions on one or more topics covered in the readings; these will be available for viewing before the synchronous weekly lectures. Lecture slides and recordings of the lectures will be made available after the class for those unable to attend during class time. 

Tutorials will follow the same format as lectures. Students will be expected to use Blackboard Collaborate, and prepare and submit 3 short essay assessments in PDF or Word format onto Quercus. Students will also be expected to answer a short timed-quiz based on readings, also on Quercus, available to students at either a 9 am or 9 pm time-period to accommodate those working in other time zones. The last final (essay) assessment will take place during the final assessment period, after the classes are over.

courses.name: Idleness and the Environment: What Does Sustainable Work Mean?

cmCourseInfo.description: In a fast-paced, high-tech world—and one that must rapidly decarbonize to address the climate crisis—the relationship between labour and environment is rapidly changing. This course explores the intersection of work and the environment, considering how ideas about leisure and idleness might offer new pathways for a more sustainable future. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Idleness and the Environment: What Does Sustainable Work Mean?

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online, synchronous. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser (Zoom and Bb Collaborate); audio capacity will be required, video capacity will be optional but encouraged. This is a seminar course (rather than a lecture course), so in-class sessions will not be recorded. Slides, when used, will be posted on Quercus just before class.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines current environmental issues for which there is no easy answer or consensus position. For instance, to help solve climate change should we generate more electricity from nuclear power-plants, which have no greenhouse gas emissions? Or instead, should we phase out nuclear plants because of possible accidents, costs and radioactive wastes? The seminar examines the scientific and political aspects of such issues and debates the pros and cons of each. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Debating & Understanding Current Environmental Issues

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online, synchronous. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser (Zoom or Bb Collaborate); audio capacity will be required, video capacity will be optional but encouraged. This is a seminar course (rather than a lecture course), so in-class sessions will not be recorded.

courses.name: Assessing Global Change: Science and the Environment

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: January 18, 2021: Section cancelled.</br>October 28, 2020: Tutorial section added

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: October 28, 2020: Tutorial section added

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: October 28, 2020: Tutorial section added

cmCourseInfo.description:
The perspective which scientists bring to the understanding and resolution of environmental concerns having global implications: atmospheric systems and climate change, the biosphere and conservation of biodiversity.

This living things and their environment breadth course is intended to fulfill the environmental literacy requirement for students in the BA programs of the School of the Environment or the living things and their environment breadth course requirement for Commerce, Humanities and Social Science students
cmCourseInfo.title: Assessing Global Change: Science and the Environment

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

ENV200H1 tutorials are offered in alternate (A) weeks. For more info, please contact David Powell at david.powell@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Online-only synchronous both lecture and tutorial

Lectures will be online synchronous at the scheduled times, but will be available to view asynchronously.  ENV200H1 tutorials are offered in alternate (A) weeks and are online synchronous only at scheduled times and mandatory.  Students need a computer with a camera and microphone in order to participate in online activities. For more info, please contact David Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: One of two foundation courses for the School’s undergraduate program. Introduces students to ways in which different disciplines contribute to our understanding of environment. Instructors and guest lecturers are drawn from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities and will present subject matter, assumptions, conceptualizations and methodologies of their disciplines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Multidisciplinary Perspectives on Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

ENV200H1 tutorials are offered in alternate (A) weeks. For more info, please contact David Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed with students encouraged to attend and participate during scheduled times, but will be available to view asynchronously.  Tutorials are online synchronous only at scheduled times and mandatory.  Students need a computer with a camera and microphone in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Building upon ENV221H1, shows how environmental studies is working to knit different disciplinary perspectives into one interdisciplinary body of knowledge; interplay of science and values in definition and framing of issues; roles of markets, politics and ethics in developing solutions; local to global scale; historical and current timeframes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Interdisciplinary Environmental Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Note: ENV222H1 tutorials are offered in alternate (A) weeks. For more info, please contact David Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be attended asynchronously. Required tutorials will be attended synchronously. An optional question and answer session with the course instructor will be held online (synchronously) each week. Days and times to be determined. Students will be able to post questions online, and instructor will record their answers.

cmCourseInfo.description: The practical, interdisciplinary and controversial nature of environmental issues, as well as the uncertainty that surrounds measures to address them demand mastery of a particular range of skills by environmental students. This course teaches the fundamental research, analysis and presentation skills required for effective environmental work. This course is for students enrolled in the Environmental Studies Major program, or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fundamental Environmental Skills
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4 FCE of courses completed.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

To request enrolment in the second round of course enrolments, please contact David Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

This is an on-line course, with lectures delivered asynchronously, with portions dedicated for group work, participation and discussion. Students need to be able to prepare and submit short essays in PDF, word or equivalent format onto Quercus and have the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Environmental Biology: Structure and Function of Ecosystems

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Aug 24, 2020: new section added

cmCourseInfo.description: This multidisciplinary course draws on elements from geology, soil science, and ecology to understand past and present environments and human impacts on landscapes and ecosystems. Emphasis on the structure, functioning and connectivity of aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. Field trips and labs. Mandatory day-long field trip on a Friday or Saturday in late September or early October (students choose which day; a small fee may be charged for transportation.) (Lab Materials Fee: $25)
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Biology: Structure and Function of Ecosystems
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO120H1/JEG100H1 (recommended)/FOR200H1/FOR201H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Practical sections meet in alternate weeks: practical sections ending with 1 start the 2nd week of classes; sections ending with 2 begin the following week of classes. Attendance at all labs including the first one is mandatory.

Delivery Instructions

Introductory lectures will be recorded and available before scheduled class meetings. An online quiz before each class meeting will encourage students to view and understand the introductory material before class. Classes will be recorded and available asynchronously, but students are encouraged to attend and participate during scheduled times. Labs are online synchronous only at scheduled times and are mandatory, so select a lab section that you can attend live. You will need a camera and microphone for active participation during lectures and labs.

Labs will meet weekly for 1.5 hours

courses.name: Physics of the Changing Environment A

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will cover basic physics of environmental processes and of measurement techniques in the atmosphere, the ocean, lake-land-forest systems, and other biological systems. It will place its work in the context of climate change and other aspects of environmental change. This course is solely intended for students who have NOT completed a previous first year physics core course, who are in one of the following programs: Environmental Science Major or Minor, Environmental Geosciences Specialist or Earth and Environmental Systems Major.
cmCourseInfo.title: Physics of the Changing Environment A
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: MAT135H1/MAT136H1/MAT137Y1/MAT157Y1/JMB170Y1, CHM136H1/CHM138H1/CHM135H1/CHM139H1/CHM151Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded for asynchronous viewing. Scheduled lecture periods will 

be used for online tutorials and office hours; tutorials will be recorded. Online practicals 

will  be held synchronously during the scheduled Practicals period.

courses.name: Physics of the Changing Environment B

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will cover basic physics of environmental processes and of measurement techniques in the atmosphere, the ocean, lake-land-forest systems, and other biological systems. It will place its work in the context of climate change and other aspects of environmental change. This course is solely intended for students who have completed a previous first year physics core course, who are in one of the following programs: Environmental Science Major or Minor, Environmental Geosciences Specialist or Earth and Environmental Systems Major.
cmCourseInfo.title: Physics of the Changing Environment B
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: MAT135H1/MAT136H1/MAT137Y1/MAT157Y1/JMB170Y1, CHM136H1/CHM138H1/CHM135H1/CHM139H1/CHM151Y1, PHY131H1/PHY132H1/PHY151H1/PHY152H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded for asynchronous viewing. Scheduled lecture periods will 

be used for online tutorials and office hours; tutorials will be recorded. Online practicals 

will  be held synchronously during the scheduled Practicals period.

cmCourseInfo.description: The Internet has deeply penetrated most aspects of society and yet we are remarkably unreflective about its impacts and sustainability. This course challenges students to critically evaluate evidence regarding the environmental and social impacts of the Internet and how the Internet contributes (or not) to goals of environmental sustainability. (ENV261H1 is intended as a Breadth Requirement course in the Social Sciences.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Is the Internet Green?
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Students must have completed a minimum of 4.0 FCEs to enrol in the course.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: BIG102Y1; ENV281H1 if taken in 2015-16 or 2016-17

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lecture and tutorials are online and synchronous, and lectures will be recorded and posted.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

Delivery Instructions

The course will be dual delivery, synchronous, but the schedule for meetings between the instructor and the students will be determined in discussions with the students.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course critically examines the concept of urban sustainability in theory and application. Case studies of ongoing urban sustainability programs in the developed and developing world help students assess the successes and failures of these programs. The course also examines the current state of research and implementation efforts toward urban sustainability. Toronto's urban sustainability and sustainable needs will be investigated through the use of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) during the course (previous experience with GIS is not required).
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Sustainability
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online, synchronous. Weekly lectures and tutorials will be posted for review asynchronously prior to class. A case study presentation and discussion and a live laboratory session will take place synchronously each week.

courses.name: Laboratory and Field Methods in Environmental Science

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on methods of sampling and analyzing natural air, water and solid Earth materials for physical, chemical and biological properties that are relevant to current environmental issues. It will integrate approaches from chemistry, physics, geology and biology, and cover techniques in field sampling, laboratory analyses and analyses of large environmental data sets. Basic concepts related to quality control will be emphasized throughout the course: sample collection and storage methods, calibration of field and lab instruments, analyses in complex matrices, errors (accuracy, precision), and detection limits. This course is for students enrolled in the Environmental Science Major program, or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director. A fee of $25 will be charged for lab supplies, lab instrument charges and technical services.
cmCourseInfo.title: Laboratory and Field Methods in Environmental Science
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ENV234H1, ENV237H1/ENV238H1, one of CHM210H1/ESS262H1, one of STA220H1/STA288H1/EEB225H1/GGR270H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

To request enrolment in the second round course course enrolments, please contact David Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

This course is online synchronous only for both chemistry (Sept-mid Oct) and ecology (mid Oct - Dec) parts.

The online-only portion of the course (Environmental Chemistry) will include lectures and live tutorials. The lectures or tutorials typically take 2 hours. For the remainder of the time in class, students will then be given time to work on assignments to compute chemical properties of pollutants, with the TA and professor present for assistance. The chemistry labs will be online, and will consist of videos and photos that help students to better understand the principles of analytical environmental chemistry. There will be several homework assignments, a final project presentation, and a final essay. Lecture slides, tutorial outlines, and assignments will be made available just ahead of the class. Live tutorials will be recorded. Students need to be able to submit essays online.

The online-only portion of the course (Ecology) will include lectures and live tutorials. This typically takes 2 hrs. For the remainder of the time in class, students will then be given time to work on assignments in R, with the TA and professor present for assistance. Sections of this course that used to be live labs or fieldwork will be online, and will consist of videos and photos that help students achieve learning objectives. There will be several R homework assignments, ecological assignments in R, and a final project. Lecture slides, readings, tutorials outlines, and assignments will be made available just ahead of the class. Live tutorials will be recorded. Students need to be able to submit essays online.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Jul 20, 2020: Course offered as Online - Synchronous

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the ways in which states negotiate and implement international agreements addressing global environmental issues, such as the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. Focus is upon factors which determine the efficacy of multilateral environmental agreements and the prospects for stronger global environmental governance.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Environmental Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be entirely online.  It will have asynchronous and synchronous components, and both are required.  

Asynchronous

There will be one 30-40 minute (approximately) lecture per week, available via downloadable .mp3.  There will be accompanying slides that you can review before or after you listen to the podcast, but you needn’t watch the slides as I speak.  In other words, you don’t have to sit at a computer to listen to the lectures.

Some weeks, there will be an additional asynchronous lecture – either by me, or in conversation with another scholar.  Other weeks, in lieu of a second asynchronous lecture, we will have a speaker join us, who will speak during the synchronous portion of the class, which will meet on Tuesdays from 12PM-1:30PM.

Synchronous

The weeks that we do not have a speaker, the synchronous portion of the class will be devoted to discussing the readings, current events and answering questions.  The synchronous portion of the class will meet every week from 12-1:00 PM and attendance is strongly recommended.  I will record these classes and make files available electronically, though they may be quite large.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to public policy and institutional foundations of public policy in Canada, with an emphasis on environmental policy in Ontario. Provides an insiders perspective on how environmental policy has been developed in Ontario.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ontario Environmental Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be made available online asynchronously. There will also be optional synchronous online sessions to ask questions. Scheduling to be determined.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores religious environmentalism, its proponents and opponents, and its core values within the Abrahamic faiths of Judaism, Christianity and Islam. Religious environmentalists have used teachings from sacred texts as exemplars of sustainability. Some, however, claim that these texts teach domination, anthropocentrism and hierarchical values. Looking at a range of worldviews, we focus on the topics of wastefulness, consumption, and simplicity. Readings about barriers, motivations, and values that inform environmental behaviour are complemented with field trips to places of worship where we will hear religious leaders speak about the environmental initiatives undertaken in their communities and see sacred spaces.
cmCourseInfo.title: Waste Not: Faith-Based Environmentalism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 FCE including ENV221H1/​ ENV222H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ENV382H1 (Special Topics in Environment: Waste Not, Want Not: Stories of Wastefulness in Religion & Society), offered in Winter 2018, Fall 2018, and Winter 2020

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be synchronous, live-streamed online per the meeting schedule, and recorded.  Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.  Planned field excursions will be replaced with alternative content.

cmCourseInfo.description: Approaches to environmental concerns are often marked by assumptions that reflect distinct worldviews positing particular understandings of the role of the human with respect to nature. This course explores sundry economic, political, scientific, religious, and moral worldviews pertaining to the environment, including environmental ethics, Gaia, ecofeminism, scientific cosmology, and indigenous perspectives.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ecological Worldviews
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

To request enrolment in the second round of course enrolment, please contact David Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

This course will be delivered as online, synchronous, per the meeting schedule.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Sep 1, 2020: Day/Time adjusted

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Sep 1, 2020: Day/Time adjusted

cmCourseInfo.description: Applied issues in aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems, with an emphasis on land-use change and its impacts on watersheds. Topics include: ecology of agro-ecosystems and other human-managed ecosystems, bio-indicators of anthropogenic impacts, ecosystem restoration, and adaptive management. Group projects address local management/restoration issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Biology: Applied Ecology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ENV234H1 and completion of 9 FCEs

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials will be online synchronous and attendance will be mandatory.

cmCourseInfo.description: Environmental design, in the context of this course, refers to design strategies that account for the ability of supporting ecosystems to continue to meet human needs and those of other lifeforms without diminishing biological diversity or environmental quality. This course takes a hands-on approach to investigating several environmental design issues: climate-responsive design, energy consumption, health and comfort, natural lighting and ventilation, and water management. Students will build up a design of a net-zero carbon residential building through several instructive design exercises during the semester, including hands-on measurement and calculation activities.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Design
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The second portion of each class is a practical.

Delivery Instructions

This is a hybrid course with lectures and tutorials delivered asynchronously. Videos of lectures and tutorials will be posted ahead of scheduled class time, and PDF versions of this content will be made available on Quercus. Synchronous discussions and tutorial followup sessions are mandatory to attend each week whether in person or online. A separately timed synchronous session may be scheduled if many students are attending from inopportune time zones. Students will be responsible for four homework assignments, a midterm and end of term quiz, and a final project submission. All assignments and quizzes will be collected and administered via Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: The impact of 7 billion people on the planet is enormous and challenges future generations. What are these impacts today and in future? What solutions and tools can avert societal collapse? Using an integrated and interdisciplinary systems approach, we explore problems and solutions to the earth’s limits to growth.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Interactions with the Environment
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: (two of ENV233H1, ENV234H1, ENV237H1/ENV238H1) or (two of CHM210H1, ENV234H1, ENV237H1/ENV238H1, ESS262H1) or (GGR201H1 + GGR203H1) or (ENV233H1 + ESS261H1) or (ESS261H1 + ESS262H1) or (CHM210H1 + CHM217H1) or (ENV221H1/ENV222H1/ENV234H1 + BIO220H1 + BIO230H1/BIO255H1) or permission of Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online pre-recorded lectures delivered according to course outline. Synchronous lecture times will be used for weekly Q/A meetings regarding lecture material, assignments and tests. Tutorial instruction will be presented synchronously during the scheduled times, and recordings posted.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examination of the linkages between human health and environment. Addresses basic principles and scientific knowledge relating to health and the environment and uses case studies to examine current environmental health issues from a health sciences perspective.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environment and Human Health
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ENV221H1/ENV222H1 or (BIO230H1/BIO255H1, and enrolment in the HMB Specialist in Health and Disease/HMB Specialist in Global Health), and completion of at least 8 FCE of courses; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director.

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online, synchronous. Lectures will be recorded and made available as per asynchronous expectations. Lecture slides will be uploaded just before lectures.

cmCourseInfo.description: Various earth systems for energy transformation, storage and transport are explored. Geological, hydrological, biological, cosmological and oceanographic energy systems are considered in the context of the Earth as a dynamic system, including the variation of solar energy received by the planet and the redistribution of this energy through various radiative, latent and sensible heat transfer mechanisms. It considers the energy redistribution role of large-scale atmospheric systems, of warm and cold ocean currents, the role of the polar regions, and the functioning of various hydrological systems. The contribution and influence of tectonic systems on the surface systems is briefly introduced, as well the important role of energy storage processes in physical and biological systems, including the accumulation of fossil fuel reserves.
cmCourseInfo.title: Terrestrial Energy Systems
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: (MAT135H1, MAT136H1)/ MAT137Y1/ JMB170Y1; BIO120H1/ CHM136H1/ CHM138H1/ CHM135H1/ CHM139H1/ CHM151Y1/ PHY131H1/ PHY132H1/ PHY151H1/ PHY152H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Both the lectures and tutorial will be online, synchronous

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the power of economic ideas in effecting environmental change. Topics include the relation of ecological economics to mainstream economics, as well as the role of financial incentives to move the environmental agenda forward.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Power of Economic Ideas
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online, asynchronous. Lectures posted weekly.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course addresses: (1) physical, technological and economic aspects of energy and electricity systems and their associated environmental impacts; (2) current international, Canadian and Ontario energy policy; (3) technological, economic and political factors influencing policy which could significantly reduce environmental impacts of energy use.
cmCourseInfo.title: Energy Policy and Environment
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

To request enrolment in LEC5101 after priority period ends on ACORN, please contact D.Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca. Engineering students must request enrolment in LEC2501 from Engineering.

Delivery Instructions

This is a hybrid course, with lectures delivered synchronously in class and online weekly (Monday, 6 - 8 pm), with portions dedicated for participation and discussion. Recordings of the lectures only (no discussion), and lecture slides and other materials, will be made available afterwards for those unable to attend during class time. Students need to be able to prepare and submit short essays in PDF, word or equivalent format onto Quercus and have the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). The grade will be based on two short written assignments and one research essay.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: October 29, 2020: Section added

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: October 29, 2020: Section added

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the impacts of the internet on environmental thinking and policy-making. Topics include the use of social media as a tool for community-building and collaborative design, the sharing economy, online protest movements, mass surveillance and its implications, and the impact of misinformation on climate denialism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Media and Environmentalism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Students must have completed a minimum of 6.0 FCEs to register for the course.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: BIG102Y1; ENV381H1 if taken in 2015-16 or 2016-17
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
ENV221H1, ENV222H1, and/or ENV261H1

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lecture and tutorials are online and synchronous, and lectures will be recorded and posted.

Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

Delivery Instructions

The course will be dual delivery, synchronous, but the schedule for meetings between the instructor and the students will be determined in discussions with the students.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to environmental law for students in Environmental Studies; legal methods available to resolve environmental problems and the scope and limits of those methods; common law and statutory tools as well as environmental assessment legislation; the problem of standing to sue and the limits of litigation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Law
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 12.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online, synchronous. Details to follow.

cmCourseInfo.description: The ecology of urban areas through consideration of the biological and physical environments, in particular how the human-constructed environment alters pre-existing biophysical conditions and interactions. Encompasses a comparative perspective to study the development of these emerging ecosystems of increasing importance given global urbanization. One or two Saturday field trips (a fee of approximately $15 may be charged for field trip transportation.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Ecology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO220H1 and at least one of EEB319H1/EEB321H1/EEB365H1/ENV334H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The course will be given synchronously per the meeting schedule with mandatory attendance. 

Some discussions will be live-streamed and recorded allowing for students to view asynchronously.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 20, 2020: Course offered as Online-Synchronous

cmCourseInfo.description:
Regular academic seminars complement off-campus work on an environmental project. The course enables students to gain practical experience of the needs and demands of professional environmental agencies. Students are given a choice of placements in a variety of sectors (such as government, NGOs, industry).

Eligible students who wish to do a work placement in the upcoming summer or fall session are must submit an application form to the Placement Coordinator by mid-January of each year. Please contact the School of the Environment’s Placement Coordinator, David Powell, at ug.office.env@utoronto.ca, or consult the School’s undergraduate courses webpage for access to the application form, instructions and application deadline.
cmCourseInfo.title: Professional Experience Course
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 10 full courses or their equivalent, including three FCE of environmental courses in the student's environmental program completed before ENV440H1 taken; or permission of Undergraduate Associate Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must apply to this course by November 15 for the following fall term. The application instructions and form can be found at: https://environment.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/course-list/ To request enrolment after November 15, please contact David Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

The course will be delivered online and synchronous, four times only during the fall term (on Thursdays 5-9 pm), with a portion of class time dedicated for participation and discussion. Recordings of the classes will be made available afterwards for those unable to attend during class time. Students need to be able to prepare and upload written assignments in Word to Quercus and have the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). There will be no term tests or final assessment during the final assessment period, after classes are over.

cmCourseInfo.description: This capstone course for the School’s core programs will explore current environmental topics, with the goal of integrating the multi- and interdisciplinary strands of each student's learning to date. This course is for students enrolled in one of the School's BA programs, or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director.
cmCourseInfo.title: Current Environmental Topics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 12.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course, with lectures delivered synchronously online weekly (Fridays from 1 - 4 pm), with portions dedicated for participation and discussion. Both lectures and discussion will be recorded, lecture slides and other materials will be made available afterwards for those unable to attend during class time. There are no tutorials. Students need to be able to prepare and submit short essays in Word Doc onto Quercus and have the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). There will be three writing assignments and no mid-term or final assessment.

cmCourseInfo.description: Scientists from within and external to the university share and discuss challenges, findings and opportunities. Specific topics (and speakers) vary from year to year but may draw from rehabilitation techniques, contaminants in our environment, environmental health, impacts on landscapes and communities, biodiversity, water, and modelling of environmental processes. This course is for students enrolled in the School of the Environment, Environmental Science Major BSc program, or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Science Seminar
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 12 FCE of courses, including ENV316H1/ENV334H1/ENV337H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For permission to enrol in this course, please contact David Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Online, synchronous. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser (Zoom and Bb Collaborate); audio capacity will be required, video capacity will be optional but encouraged. This is a seminar course (rather than a lecture course), so in-class sessions will not be recorded. Slides, when used, will be posted on Quercus just before class.

courses.name: The U of T Campus as a Living Lab of Sustainability

cmCourseInfo.description: Sustainability is a growing priority for universities all over the world. Many are developing strong operational sustainability goals and targets, and are giving increasing emphasis to teaching and research on sustainability issues. Yet few have committed at the executive level to integrating academic and operational sustainability in the context of treating their campus as a living laboratory of sustainable practice, research and teaching. Arguably, it is such living lab approaches that offer the largest potential for universities to play a significant role in the sustainability transition. This course will explore and apply the living lab concept, in the context of operational sustainability at the University of Toronto. We will begin by looking at the literature on university sustainability and the living lab concept. The bulk of the course will involve undertaking an applied research project on some aspect of campus sustainability, working in close partnership with operational staff at the University of Toronto. Students will develop the skills needed to work across disciplines and fields of study, and with non-academic partners. This course will put students to work on operational sustainability projects identified by the staff working in or with the Sustainability Office at the University of Toronto. Students will be organized into groups, each of which will be assigned one project, to be overseen by one or more U of T staff members. The bulk of the course will consist of regular meetings with the staff “clients”, with instructors, and in small groups to undertake a group project. Each group will produce a mid-term and final report, and give a mid-term and final presentation. Each student will also submit two 360 reviews of the group process. A crucial aspect of this course is the ability of students to work collaboratively together in a group environment, and to work effectively with a university staff person acting as a “client” for their work. Students will be provided with a Handbook outlining information on working in groups and the focus of the class in the second week will be on this issue. The first 360 peer review will serve to provide information on how well each group is working. Students are encouraged to discuss and resolve group process issues in the weekly group meetings, and in their regular meetings with the instructor and TA. The second 360 review will occur at the end of the term. The results of the two 360 reviews will be used, where appropriate, to adjust individual marks from the group averages.
cmCourseInfo.title: The U of T Campus as a Living Lab of Sustainability
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 10.0 FCE including ENV221H1; or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
1.0 FCE of environment-related coursework

Distribution Requirement: Social Science, Science, Humanities

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This will be an entirely online course. While there will be a few introductory lectures, delivered synchronously, most of the work done for the course will take the form of online group work on applied sustainability problems. All assignments, except for two brief 360 evaluations (worth 5% each)  are group projects. Groups will meet remotely during class time each week.

courses.name: Energy and Environment: Economics, Politics, and Sustainability

cmCourseInfo.description: This is an interdisciplinary course that examines key ideas in economics, politics and security that are essential to understanding energy and environmental issues. The course will cover energy markets, energy security, and the increasing role that sustainability plays in setting policies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Energy and Environment: Economics, Politics, and Sustainability
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Students must have completed a minimum of 10.0 FCE's to register for the course.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: BIG101Y1; ENV382H1 if taken in 2015-16 or 2016-17
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
ENV221H1, ENV222H1, ENV262H1, and/or ENV362H1

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course is delivered online synchronous, with online lectures and tutorials on Tuesdays during the 2-5 EDT time period. Lectures and tutorials are recorded and posted so that those unable to attend online at the specified course times can view the recordings. Tests are synchronous with all students writing at the same time during the scheduled Tuesday 2-5 time- slot. 

Students must have access to a computer or a tablet with a reliable internet connection in order to participate, download and upload materials, watch posted videos and write tests at specified times.”

cmCourseInfo.description: Special topics course designed for advanced Specialist and Major students in School of the Environment programs. This course is for students enrolled in a School Environmental program, or permission of the Undergraduate Associate Director.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in the Environment
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of at least 10 FCE, including (ENV221H1,ENV222H1)

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: (ENV221H1,ENV222H1) and completion of at least 10 FCE; or permission of Undergraduate Associate Director.

notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: A research project or selected topic in an area of environment not otherwise available in the Faculty, meant to develop skills in independent study of interdisciplinary topics. This course is restricted to students enrolled in a School of the Environment program. A written proposal co-signed by the student and supervisor must be submitted for approval by the Academic Associate Director of the School normally one month prior to commencing the course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies Project
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 14.0 FCE including ENV221H1/​ENV222H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students can download the application form and course outline by going to https://www.environment.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/course-list/ and clicking on the "Syllabus" link for ENV492H or ENV493H. For more information, please contact David Powell at 416-946-8100 or david.powell@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Dual delivery, asynchronous, as each student sets up a meeting schedule with their supervisor.
